qas.question: What is the first step in the Royal Institute's guidelines for education?
What is required by the second stage in the education provisions set out by RIBA?

answers.text: a two-year post graduate diploma or masters

qas.question: What does the third part of the Royal Institute's educational process contain?
How long does it take, at the least, for a student to be eligible for the title of Chartered?
What occurs between the second and third parts of the education process prescribed by the Royal Institute?
What is the first step not used in the Royal Institute's guidelines for education?

plausible_answers.text: a two-year post graduate diploma or masters

qas.question: What is not required by the second stage in the education provisions set out by RIBA?
What does the third part of the Royal Institute's educational process omit?
How long does it take, at most, for a student to be eligible for the title of Chartered?

context: The RIBA has three parts to the education process: Part I which is generally a <a0_0><b5_0>three-year first degree<b5_0/><a0_0/>, a year-out of at least one year work experience in an architectural practice precedes the Part II which is generally <a1_0><b6_0>a two-year post graduate diploma or masters<b6_0/><a1_0/>. <a4_0>A further year out<a4_0/> must be taken before the RIBA Part III <a2_0><b7_0>professional exams<b7_0/><a2_0/> can be taken. Overall it takes a minimum of <a3_0><b8_0>seven years<b8_0/><a3_0/> before an architecture student can seek chartered status.
